newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian stocks dip at open in slow trade.
newsitem.headline: Australian stocks dip at open in slow trade.

text.p: Australian shares dipped at the opening in slow trading on Monday as investors awaited some guidance on local interest rates.
A Reserve Bank of Australia board meeting is scheduled for Tuesday and, while a rate cut is not generally expected, many in the market do not rule it out completely.
At the opening, the All Ordinaries index lost 3.1 points to 2279.9.
"It's been quiet with not all that much in it," said dealer Duncan Gamble of brokerage Wilson HTM, adding that many were taking a wait and see approach to interest rate prospects.
"People are holding back to see what the Reserve bank does on interest rates."

Major miner CRA featured early, with brokers saying a combination of diminishing selling pressure following September options expiry and more favourable market sentiment than the other big miners, BHP and WMC, drove the shares 20 cents higher to A$19.15.
"There is some pressure off the market after the exercise of put options on Friday and better sentiment on CRA," Gamble said.
Falls outnumbered rises by a ratio of about seven to six, while about 42 percent of stocks traded remained steady.
